awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Tribochemically Induced Gelation and Film Formation at Metal Interfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
The research objective of this grant is to elucidate the mechanisms responsible for the formation of mechanically robust coatings at metal surfaces, arising from the combined action of mechanical and chemical forces.  While the methods employed in the project can be applied to a variety of metals, the focus will be on cobalt-based alloys that are of direct relevance to biomedical devices.  The scientific questions to be addressed by this work revolve around the nature of mixed metal/organic layers that form at the metal surface, strongly affecting its properties.

Successful completion of this project will result in a greater understanding of alloy materials that are widely used in biomedical implants, including knee and hip replacements.  The nature of the mixed metal/organic layer formed at the surface of these materials has been shown to be responsible for many of their favorable properties, but may also play a role in an observed increase in the number of painful and costly device failures.  This project will provide the necessary scientific background to develop implants that behave in a more consistent manner.  In addition, the collaborative nature of the project brings together physical science undergraduate and graduate students at Northwestern University with medical students at Rush University Medical Center.  The project is designed so that several medical students will participate in the project and develop an understanding of scientific issues underlying the use of implant materials that they may be using in future clinical practice.  Conversely, engineering undergraduate and graduate students at Northwestern will be informed of the performance requirements and constraints that are relevant to the design and use of medical implant materials.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of this project was to understand the formation of electrochemically induced coatings at metal surfaces due to the combined action of both mechanical and electrochemical driving forces, specifically for the hip implant application. This collaborative research project was performed by the Department of Materials Science and Engineering at Northwestern University and Rush University Medical Center. At Northwestern University, the primary experimental tool was the electrochemical quartz crystal microbalance (EQCM). These experiments provide detailed mechanistic information, but require the use of thin films. In order to make a comparison to the behavior of bulk alloys used in actual biomedical implants, complementary experiments with bulk materials were performed at Rush University Medical Center. 


Accomplishments: Using the EQCM tool, the role of electrochemical kinetics on the film formations was identified, the optimum potential and underlying mechanism at which film formation is promoted was determined. Interestingly, we found the role of Molybdenum on the film formation, which was supported by the inherent affinity of Molybdate ions and proteins (Fig 1). 
At Rush University, the project focused on generating the film on the bulk CoCrMo alloy and testing its tribocorrosion properties and mechanical stability, based on the outcome from QCM experimentation at Northwestern, particularly the specific role of Molybdates on film formation.  A series of tribocorrosion tests (free potential, potentiostatic and potentiodynamic) on bulk CoCrMo alloys with generated film were conducted to identify mechanical and electrochemical stability in a simulated hip-implant environment (hip simulator) (Fig 2). The protocol has been formulated to evaluate chemical and mechanical stability of the film. Other specific studies in collaborating with other experts have were carried out to test the applicability of using such a film as a pre-implant treatment method.


Outcome: An electrochemically generated tribolayer on CoCrMo implants showed superior corrosion resistance to uncoated CoCrMo and demonstrated excellent biocompatibility. The specific role of molybdate ions on the reformation of such layer was very clear, once it was exposed mechanical wear. Overall, the generation of a tribolayer on the surfaces of implant bearings prior to implantation can be a promising way to reduce tribocorrosion and improve the longevity of hip implants.


Practical significance: From a clinical perspective, understanding the corrosion and wear mechanisms of hip joint devices and protective film formation will help to guide future design and functional needs of implants. In addition, this investigation adds to the knowledge of how proteins in the synovial fluid affect corrosion kinetics of implants and understanding the role of film formation to provide protection to implant surfaces during in vivo mechanical loading conditions. Further cohesive efforts will be taken to integrate the findings from Northwestern with EQCM and translating the finding to bulk CoCrMo alloy at Rush University Medical Center.


Last Modified: 12/29/2016
Modified by: Kenneth R Shull
